text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Thursday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
JERUSALEM POST

- Three government coalition members of Knesset threaten to rebel over approved sale of Migdal Insurance to Assicurazioni Generali, Italian company which refuses to pay out on life insurance policies of Nazi Holocaust victims.
- Average monthly wages eroded by 9.2 percent in 1996, Central Bureau of Statistics says.

- Microsoft Corporation signs deal with Israel-based software developer BackWeb Technologies to expand broadcast channel and delivery options for the American company's Internet Explorer 4.0 version scheduled for release this summer.
- Tadiran, Israel's largest electronics company and a subsidiary of Koor Industries, reports 235 percent increase in earnings to 296 shekels last year from 1995.
- Bezeq Telecommunications pays stockholders intermediate dividend of 120 million shekels -- or 40 percent of its net profit during the first half of 1996.
- Israel Broadcasting Authority TV English news fights for survival.
GLOBES

- Uriel Prokatzia, dean of law faculty at Hebrew University and a drafter of new companies law, says Africa Israel cannot choose to favour value of the sabbath over business interests in operation of controversial Tel Aviv shopping mall.
- Businessmen Michael Strauss and David Federman decide to break up joint control of Elite food company. One of them will propose buying the other's shares in the coming days.
HAARETZ

- Start of Har Homa Jewish settlement put off until High Court of Justice rules on challenge raised against its construction. Compromise being weighed on Palestinian institutions in East Jerusalem: They'll remain open based on declarations they've no connection to Palestinian Authority.
- Justice office of Interior Ministry: "An expulsion or arrest order may not be issued against a foreign worker before he is informed of intention to expel him."
- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu calls "despicable" the assertion of a history of mental illness in King Hussein's family attributed in Washington Post to a political source in Jerusalem.
- Israeli army chief answers request of ultra-Orthodox Jewish members of parliament, halting educational visits of soldiers to churches and mosques in Jerusalem.
- Bank of Israel purchases $2.7 billion in foreign currency in first two months of 1997, to protect exchange rate system.
MAARIV
- Africa Israel Chairman Lev Leviev says there is no proof keeping the sabbath will harm businesses in Ramat Aviv mall but residents threaten to boycott.
- Increased protection for U.S. Ambassador Martin Indyk.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Israeli President Ezer Weizman and Arafat expected to meet this week. Arafat in interview to be published on Friday: The peace process is stopped.
- Interior Minister Eli Suissa: We'll not allow the Tel Aviv municipality to stop building permits to Africa Israel.
- Average salary at end of 1996 reached 5,251 shekels a month.
$1 = 3.730 shekels.
